html:
Etymology[edit]

From Proto-Indo-European *neḱ- (“perish, disappear”); see also noxius (“harmful”), noceō (“I hurt, harm”), nex (“murder, violent death”) (as opposed to mors), as well as Middle Welsh angheu (“death”), Breton ankou, Old Irish éc, Ancient Greek νέκυς (nékus, “a dead body”) and νεκρός (nekrós, “dead”), Old Persian 𐎻𐎴𐎰𐎹𐎫𐎹 (vi-nathayatiy, “he injures”), Avestan 𐬥𐬀𐬯𐬌𐬌𐬈𐬌𐬙𐬌‎ (nasiieiti, “disappears”), 𐬥𐬀𐬯𐬎‎ (nasu-, “corpse”), Sanskrit नश्यति (naśyati, “disappear, perish”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈne.koː/, [ˈn̪ɛ.koː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈne.ko/, [ˈnɛː.kɔ]
  • Audio (Classical)
    		(file)

Verb[edit]

necō (present infinitive necāre, perfect active necāvī, supine necātum); first conjugation

  1. I kill, murder, especially without physical wounding such as by poison or hunger
  2. (figuratively) I thwart, check

Quotations[edit]

This entry needs quotations to illustrate usage. If you come across any interesting, durably archived quotes then please add them!

Derived terms[edit]

  • ēnecō
  • internecō
  • necātor
  • necātrix
  • pernecō

Synonyms[edit]

  • interficiō
  • caedō

Antonyms[edit]

  • pariō

Descendants[edit]

  • Aromanian: nec, nicari
  • Anglo-Norman: neier
  • Catalan: negar
  • French: noyer
  • Italian: annegare
  • Norman: néyaer
  • Old French: noiier, noier
  • Picard: noéïer
  • Portuguese: anegar
  • Romanian: îneca, înecare, neca
  • Spanish: anegar

References[edit]

  • neco in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • neco in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • neco in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • to perish in the flames: igni cremari, necari
    • to be starved to death (as punishment): fame necari
  • neco in Harry Thurston Peck, editor (1898) Harper's Dictionary of Classical Antiquities, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • neco in William Smith, editor (1848) A Dictionary of Greek Biography and Mythology, London: John Murray
